parameters: It's time to learn our next set of Hiragana

I will go through each character individually and
teach you how to write it and pronounce it.
At the end of this chapter, we'll have a quiz, so
The characters we are learning in this lesson are
ha, hi, fu, he and ho. These characters follow our
pattern of a, i, u, e and o.
You'll hear examples of how to voice these
Practice writing the character in your notebook. Tips:
Use 3 strokes for this character. The vertical line on
the left has a small tail at the bottom.
Get ready for the next character!
Practice writing the character in your notebook. Tips:
Make this character with just one stroke. The curved
bottom is tilted slighty to the left.
Get ready for the next character!
You pronounce this as 'foo'. Listen carefully to the
pronunciation, as the sound is actually closer to an
Although this character is part of the 'h' set, it's
used in Japanese to represent 'f'. There's no other
set in Hiragana used for 'f' sounds.
Practice writing the character in your notebook. Tips:
Some fonts connect the outside lines to the main body
of the character. When handwriting, try to make these
outer lines separate like in the animation.
Get ready for the next character!

Our friend, the dakuten, has returned!
This guy lets us change the sound of Hiragana.
We can use dakuten on our newly learned „ÅØ series!
Adding dakuten to the characters we learned in this
lesson transforms the sound from 'h' to 'b'.
This little circle character is the dakuten's little
Can you guess what happens when we add handakuten
to our Hiragana, instead of regular dakuten?
We get a completely different sound! In this instance,
when we add dakuten to a 'h' sound, we get a 'b' sound.
With handakuten, we get a 'p' sound instead!
The handakuten are only used with this „ÅØ series of
characters. So don't fear, there's not too much to
I'll go through our 5 new characters and show you
what they become when you add dakuten & handakuten.

Write „ÅØ as normal, then add your handakuten mark in
Practice writing „Å∞ and „Å± in your notebook now.
Write „Å≤ as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
You pronounce this as 'pee'. Try not to laugh! Make
the sound short so it sounds more natural.
Write „Å≤ as normal, then add your handakuten mark in
Practice writing „Å≥ and „Å¥ in your notebook now.
Write „Åµ as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
You pronounce this as 'poo'. Just like with „Å¥, make
the sound nice and short so it sounds natural!
Write „Åµ as normal, then add your handakuten mark in
Practice writing „Å∂ and „Å∑ in your notebook now.
Write „Å∏ as normal, then add your dakuten marks in

Write „Åª as normal, then add your handakuten mark in

We've now finished this set! From this lesson, you've
learned a total of 15 new Hiragana!
